Notes: These postpositional pronouns indicate "for" or "after," as in "for or after me," etc.
Source: Geoghegan, Richard Henry. 1944. The Aleut Language. Ed. Martin, F. I. Washington, DC: United States Department of the Interior.
Syncretisms: agalkiŋin; agalkin, (1+2+3pl(incl), 1+3pl(excl), 1+2(incl), Restricted I (dual/min);, 1+3(excl), Restricted I (dual/min)

Notes: Other I includes second person plural emphatic forms ('you yourselves'). Other II is the morpheme meaning 'yourself,' which can be seen in the Other I form txitʃiŋan'an.
Source: Geoghegan, Richard Henry. 1944. The Aleut Language. Ed. Martin, F. I. Washington, DC: United States Department of the Interior.

paradigm: Verbal Subject and Object Agreement Affixes (Transitive, 3dl. object)

Notes: Transcription is phonemic. /ŋidi/ is used for "I+you" (looks like dual), "I+other(s)" (either dual or plural). McGreggor calls this form "restricted" and speculates that it means "me + either listener or at least one other (but not both)."
Source: McGregor, William. 1990. A Functional Grammar of Gooniyandi. Amsterdam; Philadelphia: J. Benjamins Pub. Co.
Harrison, Charles. 1895. Haida Grammar. Ottawa: Copp-Clark.
Harrison, Charles. 1895. Haida Grammar. Ottawa: Copp-Clark.

Notes: Plural and dual are conflated in the pronouns. Demonstratives are used for 3rd person. Other cases are derived from the nominative. (2nd person dual is fully conflated with the plural in the nominative paradigm, it does exist elsewhere in the language.)
Source: University of Arizona. Hopi Dictionary Project. 1998. Hopi Dictionary = Hopìikwa Lavàytutuveni : a Hopi-English Dictionary of the Third Mesa Dialect with an English-Hopi Finder List and a Sketch of Hopi Grammar. Tucson: University of Arizona Press.

Notes: Singular/dual can be ambiguous in third person, but can be clarified by adding the word for "two" to the end of the dual

Notes: Dual inclusive is not explicitely given (I assume it's the same as plural inclusive).
Source: Kroeker, Menno. 2001. A Descriptive Grammar of Nambikuara. International Journal of American Linguistics, Vol. 67, No. 1, pp. 1-87

Notes: Dual inclusive is not explicitely given (I assume it's the same as plural inclusive). Other 1 is translated as "me and them" (literally: 3du+1sg+3pl), and Other 2 is translated as "us and them" (litterally: 3du+1sg+3pl+1pl). These are appear to be variant of exclusive?? The grammar is not clear on what the difference is between these forms and the exclusive "we." The morpheme sĩn˥˩ can also be used when someone is reporting something as a spokesperson for a group, e.g., "I repot on behalf of my group, he came."
Source: Kroeker, Menno. 2001. A Descriptive Grammar of Nambikuara. International Journal of American Linguistics, Vol. 67, No. 1, pp. 1-87

paradigm: Verbal Subject and Object Agreement Affixes (Transitive, 3sg.fem./na class human object)
Other1: Ø- (ni class); Ø- (na class); ɳaguɽa- (a class); ɳagu- (gu class); ɳaguɽa- (ma class)
Notes: The a class prefix ɳaguɽa- is syncretic with the ma class prefix. Other II is a form of the third person masculine singular/ni class, attested only once in text.
Source: Heath, Jeffrey. 1978. Ngandi Grammar, Texts, and Dictionary. Canberra: Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies.
Eatough, Andrew. 1999. Central Hill Nisenan Texts with Grammatical Sketch. Berkeley: University of California Press

Source: Clendon, Mark. 2014. Worrora: a language of the North-West Kimberley coast. University of Adelaide Press. DOI: https://doi.org/10.20851/worrorra.; Love, J. 2000. The Grammatical Structure of the Worora Language of North-Western Australia. München: Lincom Europa.

Notes: Other I shows two allomorphs of the Set I coreferential pronoun. Other II shows two allomorphs of the Set I inanimate pronoun. Several of the pronouns given have allomorphs that depend on the phonology of the stem to which they attach. Nasalization is only written on nasal vowels that follow oral segments. Nasalization spreads to the vowel to the right of a nasal consonant, so nasal vowels that follow nasal consonants are not explicitly marked as such. When attached to noun stems, the Set I clitics indicate possession.
Source: Payne, Doris. L. and Payne, Thomas. E. 1990. Yagua. In D. C. Derbyshire and G. K. Pullum (Eds.), Handbook of Amazonian Languages: Volume 2 (pp. 249-474). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

Newman, Stanley S. 1965. Zuni Grammar. Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press.
